content: The National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002 is amended to authorize $9,839,262,000 for fiscal year 2007, with $50,000,000 allocated for Partnerships for Access to Laboratory Sciences. The National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002 authorizes funding for Partnerships for Access to Laboratory Sciences (PALS) under section 10A. The National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002 authorizes grants to high-need local educational agencies for partnerships to improve laboratory access and quality of STEM instruction at the secondary school level. Grants are awarded competitively based on merit. The National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002 authorizes grants to high-need local educational agencies for partnerships with higher education institutions to enhance STEM instruction at the secondary school level through competitive merit-based awards. The National Science Foundation Authorization Act of 2002 allows high-need local educational agencies to receive grants for partnerships with higher education institutions, businesses, and nonprofit organizations to improve STEM education at the secondary school level. The partnerships may also involve State educational agencies, public agencies, National Laboratories, or community-based organizations. The Federal government will cover a portion of the costs for activities funded by the grants. The Federal government will cover up to 33 percent of the cost for activities carried out by high-need local educational agencies through grants for STEM education partnerships with various organizations. Approved grant applications will be eligible for funding for a period of 3 fiscal years. High-need local educational agencies can receive grants for STEM education partnerships for up to 3 fiscal years. To be eligible, agencies must submit a plan developed with input from teachers, science administrators, scientists, and education researchers. To be eligible for a grant under this section, a high-need local educational agency must submit a plan developed with input from teachers, science administrators, scientists, education researchers, and other experts. The plan should outline how proposed laboratory improvements align with State mathematics and science academic standards. The plan for the grant under this section must describe how laboratory improvements align with State math and science standards and enhance STEM instruction quality. The proposed laboratory improvements and instrumentation must align with State math and science standards and enhance STEM instruction quality by producing clear learning outcomes, complementing classroom science instruction, and integrating science. The laboratory experiences are designed to produce clear learning outcomes, complement classroom science instruction, integrate science learning with content, and include student reflection and discussion. Professional development and training for teachers and school personnel in the laboratory facilities are also described. The laboratory facilities will incorporate ongoing student reflection and discussion, provide professional development for teachers, ensure safety requirements are met, and describe maintenance plans for the instrumentation. The laboratory facilities will ensure safety requirements are met, describe maintenance plans for instrumentation, and use assessment methods to expand research literature on student understanding of scientific concepts and achievement. The grant will provide financial assistance for assessment methods to expand research on the effect of laboratory science on student understanding and achievement. Funds must supplement existing programs and draw upon partner expertise to improve secondary education. Grants awarded under this section must supplement existing programs and improve secondary science education by enhancing laboratories and providing instrumentation. Grants aim to enhance secondary science education through improved laboratories and instrumentation, aligning with State academic standards. The curr_chunk focuses on improving laboratory facilities and instrumentation in alignment with State mathematics and science academic standards. This includes developing a plan for improvement, acquiring equipment and materials, and maintaining and renovating facilities. The curr_chunk focuses on funding for academic achievement standards, equipment, maintenance of laboratory facilities, teacher training, and curriculum development to integrate laboratory experience with classroom instruction. The curr_chunk highlights professional development and training for teachers, curriculum development to integrate laboratory experience with classroom instruction, training in laboratory safety for school personnel, and hands-on laboratory experiences to encourage interest in science and engineering. The curr_chunk focuses on training in laboratory safety for school personnel, hands-on laboratory experiences to encourage interest in science and engineering, and tools development for evaluation. The Opportunities Act focuses on training in mathematics, science, engineering, and technology, preparing individuals for postsecondary studies in these fields, developing evaluation tools, and other activities determined by the Director. Grants awarded under this section cannot be used for construction of new facilities. The Director determines activities funded under this subsection, including those that accomplish the goals. Grants cannot be used for new facility construction. High-need local educational agencies must submit an application for a grant containing specified information. High-need local educational agencies must submit an application to the Director for a grant under this section, including a description of the partnership, the plan, and activities to be implemented. The application for a grant must include a description of the partnership, the plan, and activities to be carried out aligned with State academic standards. The grant application must include a description of activities aligned with State academic standards and based on relevant research. The grant application must include activities promoting student achievement in mathematics and science based on research and best practices to improve performance and instruction quality. Activities encouraging individuals' interest should also be described. The grant application must describe how activities will improve student performance in mathematics and science, as well as encourage the interest of individuals in STEM fields. The grant application must include a description of how activities will enhance student performance in mathematics, science, engineering, and technology, and prepare individuals for postsecondary studies in these fields. It should also outline how changes in student achievement will be assessed and how the partnership will evaluate its success. The grant application must include a description of how activities will enhance student performance in mathematics, science, engineering, and technology, and prepare individuals for postsecondary studies in these fields. It should also outline how changes in student achievement will be assessed, how the partnership will evaluate its success, and how programmatic assessments will be made available to the research community. The Director will consider these factors when reviewing applications. The grant application must describe how activities will enhance student performance in STEM fields and prepare them for postsecondary studies. The Director will evaluate the partnership's ability to effectively carry out programs based on research and best practices to increase student achievement. The grant application will be evaluated based on the partnership's ability to effectively carry out programs aligned with State standards and likely to increase student achievement. The partnership should demonstrate activities that can be widely implemented. The grant application will be evaluated based on the partnership's alignment with State standards, potential to increase student achievement, likelihood of widely implementable activities, and encouragement of interest in individuals identified in the Science and Engineering Equal Opportunities Act. The Director will evaluate the program established under this section, focusing on accountability and dissemination. The evaluation will assess the extent to which activities encourage interest in mathematics, science, engineering, and technology among individuals identified in the Science and Engineering Equal Opportunities Act, preparing them for postsecondary studies in these fields. The Director will evaluate the program to assess best practices and materials developed by partnerships, comparing their effectiveness in preparing individuals for postsecondary studies in STEM fields. The Director will evaluate the program to assess best practices and materials developed by partnerships in STEM fields and compare their effectiveness with other agencies. Dissemination of results to the public will be done by the Director. The Director will evaluate STEM partnerships funded by various agencies and compare their effectiveness. Results will be disseminated to the public and relevant congressional committees. The Director will disseminate results of STEM partnership evaluations to congressional committees and the public, making effective materials widely available. Technical assistance will be provided upon request for high-need areas. The Director will make effective materials developed under the program widely available to the public. Technical assistance will be provided to high-need local educational agencies upon request. The Director will provide technical assistance to high-need local educational agencies in developing grant applications and activities. An annual meeting of these agencies will be convened by the Director in consultation with the Secretary of Education. The Director, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will convene an annual meeting of high-need local educational agencies that are grant recipients to promote national collaboration. Additionally, the Director will report on coordination to the Committee on Science and the Committee on Education. The Director, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will provide an annual report to congressional committees on how the grant program for high-need local educational agencies is coordinated nationally. The Director, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will submit an annual report to congressional committees on the coordination of the grant program for high-need local educational agencies with the program authorized under part B of title II of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The report must be submitted concurrently with the President's annual budget request. The Director, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will submit an annual report to congressional committees on the coordination of the grant program for high-need local educational agencies with the program authorized under part B of title II of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The report must be submitted concurrently with the President's annual budget request. Definitions in this section include 'high-need local educational agency' and 'National Laboratory'. The term 'high-need local educational agency' refers to an agency eligible for a grant under the Rural and Low-Income School Program. The term 'National Laboratory' is defined as per the Energy Policy Act of 2005.
